nodes.bodyText:
I generally update dependencies when the result still works.
In this case there were also a few CVEs that were fixed and more compatibility in building in the various clouds: https://github.com/git-commit-id/git-commit-id-maven-plugin/issues?q=milestone%3A4.0.0

nodes.bodyText: this seems quite Flink developer oriented and I'm not convinced we need it. How would this be exposed to the developer?
I agree. Removing it.
I would off on this one; it is currently not clear how this will be used and it will make more sense in the follow-up PR.
I agree. Removing it.
this isn't used anywhere?

 			</plugin>

+						</configuration>
+					</execution>
+				</executions>
+				<configuration>
+					<replacements>
+						<replacement><token>@project.version@</token><value>${project.version}</value></replacement>

+
+						<replacement><token>@git.build.time@</token><value>${git.build.time}</value></replacement>
+						<replacement><token>@git.build.version@</token><value>${git.build.version}</value></replacement>

nodes.bodyText: The $ branch means that it will fail if I just run it in the IDE; instead we should return the unknown value.
Ok, I'll update that behaviour.

        Suggested change

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
why this distinction?
Fixed
Why are we adding this?
I added this because while debugging IntelliJ uses the toString method to show the content of a record ... which is messy if it falls back to the Object.toString(). I'll remove it.
private?
(since Versions is private anyway so you couldn't do anything interesting with it)
Ah, yes. I'll fix that.
We usually don't encapsulate singletons. What is the goal behind the holder? (I haven't seen this before)

It is a trick to ensure the instantiation of the singleton does not incur any race conditions.
This is a safe solution because the class instantiation of the VersionsHolder is guaranteed to be single threaded.
Another way to do this is to make the getVersionsInstance synchronized which makes it needlessly slow.
This is also the reason why the VersionsHolder is private.
Are you saying that having private static final Versions INSTANCE = new Versions(); directly in EnvironmentInformation would not be thread-safe?
No that is thread safe too. The way I did it the initialization is done on first use instead of on class loading. Which do you prefer?
Ah, got it. hmm...we usually use the class-loading one I believe, but I suppose  it's fine either way
